title: 113_s1546
content: The Act titled "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" establishes minimum state requirements. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" mandates that each State receiving funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must establish minimum requirements for concussion safety and management plans in local educational agencies. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" requires States to establish minimum requirements for concussion safety and management plans in educational agencies, including training school personnel and providing forms for reporting and recordkeeping, treatment plans, and prevention strategies. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" mandates States to set up concussion safety plans in educational agencies, including training personnel and providing prevention strategies. It also encourages support for students recovering from concussions, involving a multidisciplinary team for resuming athletic and academic activities. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" requires schools to have a team overseeing the recovery of students with concussions, provide academic accommodations, and promote best practices for safety and management. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" mandates public schools to disseminate information on concussion safety, apply uniform best practice standards, and post peer-reviewed scientific evidence on concussions for students' awareness. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" requires public schools to provide information on the risks, actions to take, and signs of concussions. Additional information may cover the definition of concussions, ways to reduce their occurrence, and their impact on academic performance. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" mandates that if a student is suspected of having a concussion, they must be immediately removed from athletic activities and cannot return on the same day. The "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2013" requires immediate removal of students suspected of having a concussion from athletic activities. The designated individual must report injury details to the parent or guardian and the student can only resume activities with a health professional's approval. Before a student resumes participation in school-sponsored athletic activities after sustaining a concussion, the school must receive a written release from a healthcare professional stating the student is capable of resuming activities. The release may also require the student to follow a recovery plan coordinated with appropriate parties. If a State fails to comply with guidelines for managing concussions in student athletes, funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 may be reduced by 5 percent for the following fiscal year. Compliance includes coordinating periods of rest and gradually reintroducing cognitive and physical demands to prevent symptom reemergence. If a State fails to comply with concussion management guidelines for student athletes, funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 may be reduced by 10 percent for the following fiscal year. The Secretary of Education must notify the State and Congress before implementing any fund reductions. SEC. 3. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not impact civil or criminal liability under Federal or State law. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines a concussion as a mild traumatic brain injury caused by a blow to the head or body, disrupting normal brain functioning and altering mental state. Symptoms include confusion, disorientation, memory dysfunction, and loss of consciousness. A concussion is defined as a mild traumatic brain injury resulting from a blow to the head or body, causing symptoms like confusion, disorientation, memory issues, and loss of consciousness lasting less than 30 minutes. Symptoms can also include physical, cognitive, emotional symptoms, and difficulty sleeping, occurring with or without loss of consciousness during sports or recreational activities. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to traumatic brain injury management in children, including the roles of health care professionals, local educational agencies, states, and related services personnel. The curr_chunk defines "services personnel" as individuals providing services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, and "school-sponsored athletic activity" as various physical education and sports programs organized by schools.
